pullRequest.body:
Add some theorems on the equality condition of the weighted AM-GM inequality for real-valued nonnegative functions, referring to `geom_mean_arith_mean_weighted_eq_iff` in `Mathlib/Analysis/MeanInequalities.lean`.


---
<!-- 

The discussion in zulip is here: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Adding.20Equality.20Conditions.20to.20MeanInequalities.20in.20Mathlib4.

It's my first time to make a pr in mathlib4. I plan to incrementally add equality conditions of the cases in `MeanInequalities.lean` to the original file and commit. Once it grows large enough, I'll organize them into a separate file.

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [3982833da0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19435/commits/3982833da01ddb4ba061b9075eccb052282d9346)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ geom_mean_eq_arith_mean_weighted_iff`
`+ geom_mean_eq_arith_mean_weighted_iff'`
`+ geom_mean_lt_arith_mean_weighted_iff_of_pos`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
The usual way to prove the equality case of an inequality is to first prove its strict inequality case. Could you please do that here? Thanks!

> The usual way to prove the equality case of an inequality is to first prove its strict inequality case. Could you please do that here? Thanks!

Do you mean I should write a new theorem to handle the strict inequality case first, or just modify the current proof to include it as a step?

something like this?
```
theorem geom_mean_lt_arith_mean_weighted' (w z : Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hw : ‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 < w i)
    (hw' : ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i = 1) (hz : ‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 < z i) (hzne : ‚àÉ j ‚àà s, ‚àÉ k ‚àà s, z j ‚â† z k) :
    ‚àè i ‚àà s, z i ^ w i < ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i * z i := by
  sorry
```
You should write a new theorem üòÑ

The strict inequality equivalent condition is done (maybe?).

I ended up splitting the equality case into two versions to make proving the strict inequality more convenient (yes, I used the equality condition to prove the strict inequality, which was quite easy to write).
As for the version where weights can be zero, I tried writing the strict inequality case, but the equivalent condition turned out to be too complex.

> The usual way to prove the equality case of an inequality is to first prove its strict inequality case. Could you please do that here? Thanks!

But I think `eq_iff` case is enough. Since we already have `le`, so if it's not `eq` it must be `lt`.

Looks good now!

maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12111043175/job/33762319255)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12111043175/job/33762319381)
Thanks for the PR!
Looks good, though I'm not familiar with elementary inequalities.
Here are a few more small tips. This is looking pretty good now, thanks for the nice contribution!

Can you adapt the proof to show this?
```suggestion
theorem geom_mean_arith_mean_weighted_eq_iff (w z : Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hw : ‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 ‚â§ w i)
    (hw' : ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i = 1) (hz : ‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 ‚â§ z i) :
    ‚àè i ‚àà s, z i ^ w i = ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i * z i ‚Üî ‚àÄ j ‚àà s, 0 < w j ‚Üí z j = ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i * z i := by
```
Sure, I‚Äôd be happy to do that.

I noticed that in a similar lemma `strictConvexOn_exp.map_sum_eq_iff'`, it uses `w j ‚â† 0 ‚Üí` rather than `0 < w j ‚Üí`. Is it better to use `‚â†` or `<` here?

```
lemma StrictConvexOn.map_sum_eq_iff' (hf : StrictConvexOn ùïú s f) (h‚ÇÄ : ‚àÄ i ‚àà t, 0 ‚â§ w i)
    (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àë i ‚àà t, w i = 1) (hmem : ‚àÄ i ‚àà t, p i ‚àà s) :
    f (‚àë i ‚àà t, w i ‚Ä¢ p i) = ‚àë i ‚àà t, w i ‚Ä¢ f (p i) ‚Üî
      ‚àÄ j ‚àà t, w j ‚â† 0 ‚Üí p j = ‚àë i ‚àà t, w i ‚Ä¢ p i
```

I wrote two more version based on the first version, `geom_mean_arith_mean_weighted_eq_iff'` and `geom_mean_arith_mean_weighted_eq_iff''`.
But the linter said something like "missing a doc-string".
I'm not sure how to properly document this -- any guidance? Thanks.

```
theorem geom_mean_arith_mean_weighted_eq_iff' (w z : Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hw : ‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 ‚â§ w i)
    (hw' : ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i = 1) (hz : ‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 ‚â§ z i) :
    ‚àè i ‚àà s, z i ^ w i = ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i * z i ‚Üî ‚àÄ j ‚àà s, w j ‚â† 0 ‚Üí z j = ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i * z i := by
  have h (i) (_ : i ‚àà s) : w i * z i ‚â† 0 ‚Üí w i ‚â† 0 := by aesop
  have h' (i) (_ : i ‚àà s) : z i ^ w i ‚â† 1 ‚Üí w i ‚â† 0 := by aesop
  rw [‚Üê sum_filter_of_ne h, ‚Üê prod_filter_of_ne h', geom_mean_arith_mean_weighted_eq_iff]
  ¬∑ simp
  ¬∑ simp (config := { contextual := true }) [(hw _ _).gt_iff_ne]
  ¬∑ rwa [sum_filter_ne_zero]
  ¬∑ simp_all only [ne_eq, mul_eq_zero, not_or, not_false_eq_true, and_imp, implies_true, mem_filter]

theorem geom_mean_arith_mean_weighted_eq_iff'' (w z : Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hw : ‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 ‚â§ w i)
    (hw' : ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i = 1) (hz : ‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 ‚â§ z i) :
    ‚àè i ‚àà s, z i ^ w i = ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i * z i ‚Üî ‚àÄ j ‚àà s, 0 < w j ‚Üí z j = ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i * z i := by
  have h (i) (a : i ‚àà s) : w i * z i ‚â† 0 ‚Üí 0 < w i := fun _ => lt_of_le_of_ne' (hw i a) (by aesop)
  have h' (i) (a : i ‚àà s) : z i ^ w i ‚â† 1 ‚Üí 0 < w i := fun _ => lt_of_le_of_ne' (hw i a) (by aesop)
  rw [‚Üê sum_filter_of_ne h, ‚Üê prod_filter_of_ne h', geom_mean_arith_mean_weighted_eq_iff]
  ¬∑ simp
  ¬∑ simp (config := { contextual := true }) [(hw _ _).gt_iff_ne]
  ¬∑ have : filter (fun x => 0 < w x) s = filter (fun x => w x ‚â† 0) s := by
      apply filter_congr
      exact fun x hx => ‚ü®fun a => (ne_of_lt a).symm, fun a => lt_of_le_of_ne (hw x hx) a.symm‚ü©
    rwa [this, sum_filter_ne_zero]
  ¬∑ simp_all only [ne_eq, mul_eq_zero, not_or, not_false_eq_true, and_imp, implies_true, mem_filter]
```

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/56d679f4-6656-463d-8f86-3ff0abed4f25)
`‚â†` is better, sorry for the misguidance. I think here the best move is to completely remove your first lemma in favor of your second lemma

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
```
Maybe it should named `geom_mean_eq_arith_mean_weighted_iff_aux_of_pos`
Then maybe the 'aux' is not necessary?

But the conclusion `‚àÄ j ‚àà s, z j = ‚àë i ‚àà s, w i * z i` is not the negation of your last one `‚àÉ j ‚àà s, ‚àÉ k ‚àà s, z j ‚â† z k`. If I understand correctly, this `aux` is not the final simplified result, but only an intermediate step.
I've made the changes as suggested. Thank you for your review and feedback!
Maybe it should named `geom_mean_eq_arith_mean_weighted_iff`

Maybe it should named `geom_mean_lt_arith_mean_weighted_iff_of_pos`. But in my opinion I prefer only `geom_mean_eq_arith_mean_weighted_iff_of_pos` (condition becomes `‚àÄ j ‚àà s, ‚àÄ k ‚àà s, z j = z k`), and the `lt` version is leave for caller (we have `contrapose`, `push_neg`, etc.).

In this theorem, `w` and `z` can be inferred from the other arguments ‚Äì you can't prove that `‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 < w i` without knowing what `w` is ‚Äì so the usual library convention would be to make them implicit. That is, replace the round brackets with curly ones, `{w z : Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù}`. (Same applies to the other theorems here too.)

On another matter: is this first theorem only useful as a stepping-stone to the theorems later on in the file (as the `aux` in the name suggests)? If it is no longer useful once those theorems are proved (i.e. if the later theorems trivially imply it) then you can mark it as `private`, so it doesn't appear in the reference manual and can't be used outside this file.

Thanks for the review.
I found two simililar theorem in [Jasen.lean](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/Analysis/Convex/Jensen.lean), `StrictConvexOn.map_sum_eq_iff` and `StrictConvexOn.map_sum_eq_iff'` ([here](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/search.html?sitesearch=https%3A%2F%2Fleanprover-community.github.io%2Fmathlib4_docs&q=StrictConvexOn.map_sum_eq_iff)), and I followed the same style to write the two theorems here. I'm not sure if I should make the 'aux' one private or rename it properly. (I also tried to name it something like `geom_mean_eq_arith_mean_weighted_iff' `, but the linter didn't accept the apostrophe)

Aha! The linter shouldn't complain about the apostrophe as long as there is a doc-string. In your case you clearly meant to make a doc-string (the text preceding the theorem); but doc-strings need to start with `/--` (two dashes), not `/-` (one dash) which is just an ordinary comment. So this needs to be fixed anyway; and it will have the side-effect of stopping the linter complaining. 

I had overlooked this until now, so it's lucky that you made the remark about linters.

> In this theorem, `w` and `z` can be inferred from the other arguments ‚Äì you can't prove that `‚àÄ i ‚àà s, 0 < w i` without knowing what `w` is ‚Äì so the usual library convention would be to make them implicit. That is, replace the round brackets with curly ones, `{w z : Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù}`. (Same applies to the other theorems here too.)

I found all the other theorems in this file use `(w z : Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù)`. If we change them all to `{w z : Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù}`, would it cause significant compatibility issues with existing code?
Changing the arguments to implicit is a routine task but might be a little tedious. If you don't want to take on this re-factoring job, then don't feel you have to.
Generally we discourage chaining together multiple tactics on one line.
What does `simp only [(¬∑ ‚àò ¬∑)]` do? I've never seen this syntax before.

While reading the `geom_mean_le_arith_mean_weighted` theorem earlier in the same file, I noticed this. Deleting it doesn't affect local compilation, but I kept it in case it was a historical issue. Perhaps the code is a bit outdated due to Lean version differences?

I'll delete it in my theorem. What about the original `geom_mean_le_arith_mean_weighted` theorem?
I think it's a hangover from an old version. If it's not needed please delete it (here and in the earlier proof). Always use as few simp lemmas as you can.

> What does `simp only [(¬∑ ‚àò ¬∑)]` do? I've never seen this syntax before.

I think it's equivalent to `Function.comp` or `Function.comp_def`. `(¬∑ ‚àò ¬∑)` is for cuteness üòÇ
More line breaks, and putting the `<;>` at the end of lines rather than the beginning, would be easier to read.

These `have`s seem to be duplicating existing lemmas in the library, eg the first is just [left_ne_zero_of_mul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/GroupWithZero/Basic.html#left_ne_zero_of_mul).

I tried but didn't find existing lemmas for the second `have`, but it can be written in three lines as follow:
```
have h' (i) (_ : i ‚àà s) : z i ^ w i ‚â† 1 ‚Üí w i ‚â† 0 := by
    by_contra!
    obtain ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü© := this
    simp only [h2, rpow_zero, ne_self_iff_false] at h1
```
Do I need to rewrite the aesop for the second `have`?
Either way is fine, you can use this or aesop; it's up to you.
There was a Zulip thread recently about a new cleaner syntax for this, something like `simp +contextual [foo]`

```suggestion
weighted version of the AM-GM inequality for real-valued nonnegative functions. -/
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: an equality condition for AM-GM inequality
